ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Chinese modern fiction and their underlying messages/critique of Chinese society.

I read 7 important works in modern Chinese fiction. I learned a wide range of vocabulary, often literary in nature. I learned about Chinese history, culture, and literature. My ability to read traditional characters improved dramatically.
Chinese reading and writing skills.
How to read/interpret 20th century Chinese literature, how to write personal essays in Chinese

I learned a lot about the time period around from the end of the Qing Dynasty to the Cultural Revolution. Chinese traditional culture and values, Chinese people's views about them. Also I learned a lot of vocab and grammar, including literary/formal and slang. Readings were short stories by famous authors whom Professor Su knows personally, so I believe it's helpful to have read these works that are influential and widely read in China.
I learned a lot about Chinese culture, and developed my ability to read and write Chinese.

We read around seven works by major modern Chinese writers. We learned a lot of great vocabulary (had dictations, exams, and homework exercises like in 150-level Chinese classes) and also worked on the skill of reading in traditional characters.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: No weaknesses! Strengths: the readings (theyre a mix of really important and interesting works in modern Chinese fiction), the professor (Su Wei is one of a kind), assignments (none take too long or are that difficult but all help you build Chinese language skills)

Strengths include the curation of material that gradually becomes more difficult as the semester goes on.
Weaknesses include clarity of assignment due dates.

Strengths: Interesting and insightful readings. Su laoshi always had interesting background about the authors, Chinese society, proverbs, and personal anecdotes!
Weaknesses: Class organization could have been better
The materials covered in the course are very interesting. However it was sometimes a little bit lacking in organization (meaning sometimes it wasn't very clear exactly what the homework was).

Strengths: Professor is really passionate and willing to share in depth the historical and philosophical background behind the stories, authors, time period, and Chinese culture. He even shares personal anecdotes and life advice. His feedback on essays and in-class explanations of how to write essays helped me improve a lot. Midterms tested on exactly what we learned, so students can learn a lot without being stressed and confused. I believe the value of this class exceeds plain language learning because of Professor Su. 
Weaknesses: The syllabus didn't match what we actually did in class at times. At the same time, the TA, who managed Canvas, followed the syllabus. As a result, it was at times confusing, for example: when to submit what assignment where.

This class is somewhat between a seminar and lecture in format, which I found to be very effective. I really enjoyed listening to Prof. Su lecture about the stories we were studying as well as the cultural/historical/political backdrop of the authors' lives. 

Sometimes the pacing of the assignments felt a little too fast, especially towards the end of the term. Reading in traditional characters for the first time was extremely time consuming, although I definitely found it a great skill to work on. I don't know if there is an alternative way to ease students into it, like perhaps a reference sheet for the extremely common characters; it wasn't too difficult, just required a lot of dictionary-checking.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I thought the course ran as smoothly as it could. It just felt like a normal seminar. Wed submit assignments via Canvas or through Google Drive instead of in-person, which I didnt think was too much of a hassle. If he wanted to show us certain characters, Su Wei would just write them on a piece of paper and hold the paper up to the camera until we could copy them down.
Generally it succeeded. Perhaps class organization could have been better. Also, the course reading was a bit hard to annotate in PDF form, so I often searched for them online.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Absolutely! If you have finished the standard Chinese sequence, and you are interested in literature, definitely take this course (or any other course taught by Su Wei). The readings are incredibly compelling, and Su Wei will walk you through them in detail in class. Youll also learn random bits of Chinese history, thought, and literature that are really interesting.
If you're interesting in Chinese literature, history, and language, this course is a must-take at Yale!
Yes! If you are eager to read actual Chinese literature instead of textbooks essays and learn more about Chinese history and thought, this class is great!
Yes, if you like learning Chinese language, culture, and history.
Yes!  I learned a lot and the class was very interesting.
Yes! If you're interested in Chinese literature, you should for sure take this class, or any other class taught by Prof. Su. I wish I had taken this class earlier in my time at Yale.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: N/A  all classes were held live over Zoom in a seminar style.
N/A
Readings from textbook, canvas handouts
